Heterogeneous asymmetric catalysis based on earth-abundant carbon materials put together the advantages for the ease of separation, simple regeneration, and high stability of solid catalysts as well as acts as low-cost, environmentally friendly metal-free alternative to the metal-based catalysts. Two new bifunctional carbocatalysts [ (S,S) and (R,R) GO-PATU] were prepared by anchoring enantiomerically pure organosilanes bearing primary amine and thiourea groups to the graphene oxide (GO) skeleton covalently via silane coupling reaction. The surface modification of GO was analyzed by a combination of Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron spectroscopy (TEM) techniques. The catalytic performances of graphene-based materials were investigated in the asymmetric Michael addition reactions of α,α-disubstituted-aldehydes to nitrostyrenes and N-substituted-maleimides. The effects of solvents and Brønsted basic or acidic additives were evaluated using both catalysts and good yields (up to 85%) and stereoselectivities (up to 95% ee) were obtained in dichloromethane at room temperature in the presence of l - and d -camphorsulfonic acid. Besides, recycling and reusing studies of the catalysts were successfully performed. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal-free asymmetric catalysis Heterogeneous catalyst Bifunctional carbocatalyst Graphene oxide Asymmetric Michael addition 1 Introduction Carbon-based catalysts defined as carbocatalysts are considered as heterogeneous versions of organocatalysts [1]. Carbocatalysts differ from organocatalysts in terms of reactive species: while carbon in the former and organic molecule rather than carbon materials in the latter constitutes the main component [2]. They transform the metal-free characteristic of homogeneous organocatalysts to easily recoverable and reusable multifunctional surface materials. Low cost, availability from a variety of renewable resources and being environmentally friendly make carbocatalysts attractive and their participation as catalysts in many important organic reactions increases recently [3]. Graphene, composed of a single layer sp2 bonded carbons arranged in a honeycomb crystal lattice, has been accepted as a shining star of carbon materials due to its extraordinary physical/mechanical, electronic, thermal, optical and chemical properties in recent years [4,5]. One of the significant feature of graphene is its large specific surface area that makes it a unique platform for developing heterogeneous catalytic systems. Adsorption and diffusion processes that are indispensable stages of heterogeneous catalysis can be facilitated by this large surface area. In addition, graphene-related materials like graphene oxide (GO) sheet which contain a certain degree of defects have a large number of oxygen functionalities such as carboxyl, epoxide and hydroxyl on the basal planes and the edges [6,7]. Chemical modifications of these functional groups generate homogeneous colloidal suspensions that could be used in various solvents for different catalytic applications. Thus, graphene oxide and its chemically modified derivatives were successfully used in several organic transformations such as Aldol addition and Knoevenagel condensation [8,9], Friedel–Crafts reaction [10,11], Michael and aza-Michael addition [12,13], and multicomponent reactions [14,15]. In addition to this increased interest, various graphene-based chiral hybrid materials were also prepared and applied for pre-designed purposes such as chiral separation, chiral detection, biomedical applications and asymmetric catalysis [16]. In the asymmetric catalytic applications of modified graphenes, enantiomerically pure groups attached to graphene sheets via non-covalent interactions such as hydrogen-bonding or/and ionic interaction [17,18] or covalently from the edges or from surface [19,20] have successfully applied mainly to the enantioselective Aldol reaction. The Michael addition reaction, also known as a conjugate addition, is one of the most powerful tool for construction carbon–carbon bonds in organic chemistry. Asymmetric version of Michael addition reactions is particularly important, because thus obtained functional groups offer broad opportunities for subsequent reactions that lead to formation of valuable pharmaceuticals [21]. Application of metal-free modified graphene oxide carbocatalysts in asymmetric catalysis is still rare and open to improve especially in terms of the variety of reaction types applied, stereoselectivity and reusability. So herein, in order to widen the application of metal-free modified graphene oxide carbocatalysts in asymmetric synthesis and diversify the reaction types applied we grafted graphene oxide with enantiomerically pure primary amine thiourea units and explored catalytic performances on the enantioselective Michael addition reactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 General information General information about all materials and reagents used in this work, the characterization data for enantiomerically pure organosilanes and chiral HPLC data for Michael addition products were given in Supplementary Material. 2.2 Synthesis of enantiomerically pure cyclohexane-1,2-diamine-based organosilanes Chiral isothiocyanates 2a and 2b were readily prepared from trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane in two steps with good overall yields following the literature procedures [22,23]. In order to obtain protected organosilanes 3a–3b according to the method described by Sancenón et al. [24]., protected isothiocyanate 2a or 2b (1.72 g, 6.0 mmol) was taken into a two-necked 100 mL round bottom flask under nitrogen atmosphere and dissolved in 25 mL of dry CH2Cl2. To the stirred solution, (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (1.33 g, 6.0 mmol) was added dropwise via a syringe and the solution was stirred at room temperature. After 24 h, the solvent was removed by evaporation under vacuum, and the product was isolated by flash column chromatography on silica gel using hexane/ethyl acetate (10/1 to 3:1, v/v) as an eluent to give 3a (2.65 g, 87%) and 3b (2.53 g, 83%) as a yellowish solid. Protected organosilane 3a; FTIR (cm−1): 3348, 2972, 2934, 1768, 1695, 1545, 1444, 1392, 1299, 1075, 951, 775, 721. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.85–7.75 (m, 2H), 7.73–7.66 (m, 2H), 6.05–5.90 (m, 1H), 5.69 (bs, 1H), 4.69 (bs, 1H), 4.05–3.94 (m, 1H), 3.81 (q, J = 7.0 Hz, 6H), 3.25 (bs, 2H), 2.75–2.10 (m, 2H), 2.0–1.72 (m, 3H), 1.64–1.27 (m, 5H), 1.23 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 9H), 0.63–0.49 (m, 2H) ppm; 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 181.4, 168.9, 134.0, 131.8, 123.3, 58.5, 54.9, 33.4, 29.0, 25.4, 24.6, 22.2, 18.3, 7.7 ppm. The protected organosilane 3a or 3b (2.4 g, 4.73 mmol) and hydrazine hydrate (2.4 mL, 85% in H2O) were dissolved in EtOH (40 mL) and refluxed for 1 h. After the completion of the reaction confirmed by TLC, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature. 50 mL of Et2O was added and the mixture was filtered off. The residue was dissolved in 50 mL of CHCl3, extracted with 2 × 25 mL H2O and dried over MgSO4. The solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure and 4a/4b were obtained in quantitative yields as colorless liquids and were used in the next step without further purification. 2.3 Preparation of graphene-based materials Due to low solubility of organosilane compounds in toluene, we considered the literatures about silane coupling reactions with GO in EtOH [25,26]. For this purpose, firstly, in order to obtain single-layer graphene oxide sheets 0.7 g GO, prepared based on our previous publication [20], was sonicated in 50 mL of EtOH for 1 h. Then 0.9 g chiral amine–thioure organosilane compound 4a or 4b dissolved in 50 mL of EtOH and added dropwise to the above GO suspension. The mixture was refluxed for 8 h, cooled to room temperature and centrifuged at 12,000 rpm for 20 min. The obtained black colored material (abbreviated as (S,S)-GO-PATU and (R,R)-GO-PATU ) was washed with EtOH/H2O mixture (50 mL) for 4 times and dried under vacuum at 40 °C for 48 h and stored at dark. 2.4 General procedure for asymmetric Michael reactions To a mixture of nitroalkene (1 equiv.) or maleimide (1 equiv.), (S,S) or (R,R) GO-PATU (25 mg) and additive (0.015 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (1.0 mL) was added isobutyraldehyde 5a or cyclopentanecarboxaldehyde 5b (4 eq. or 5 eq.) at room temperature. The mixture was stirred until the comsuming of starting material had been detected by TLC (24 to 72 h). Then, the mixture was centrifuged and the DCM layer was separated. The solvent was evaporated and the residue was purified through a 10 cm pad of silica gel placed in a Pasteur pipette by flushing hexane/ethyl acetate mixture. Racemic samples of the Michael adducts were prepared using a racemic primary amine thiourea organocatalyst. All addition products 7a–7g and 9a–9f are known and the analytical and spectroscopic data are in accordance with those reported (see Supplementary material) [27,28]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of graphene-based carbocatalysts In order to obtain graphene-based bifunctional catalysts by decorating graphene surface with enantiomerically pure primary amine-thiourea groups, first we prepared enantiomerically pure protected organosilanes 3a and 3b following the synthetic route given in Scheme 1 . Characterization of 3a and 3b was achieved by 1H and 13C NMR (Fig. S2, Supplementary material). From 1H NMR data, the quartet at 3.81 and the triplet at 1.23 ppm were assigned to the methylene (–CH2–) and the methyl (–CH3) protons of the ethoxy group. The aromatic protons were observed between 7.85–7.66 ppm as two multiplets. In the 13C NMR, thiourea quaternary and phthalimide carbonyl carbons were observed at 181.4 and 168.9 ppm, respectively. Deprotection of phthalimide group by refluxing with hydrazine hydrate in EtOH afforded enantiomerically pure organosilanes 4a and 4b bearing primary amine and thiourea groups. As shown in Scheme 2, silane coupling of 4a and 4b with GO was carried out in EtOH and (S,S) / (R,R) GO-PATU were obtained as black colored materials. Both structural and morphological characterization of the prepared graphene-based heterogeneous catalysts were performed using FT–IR, Raman, XPS, SEM and TEM in detail. FT–IR spectral analysis was used to demonstrate the presence of functional groups and accomplished conversion of them. As shown in Fig. 1 a, in addition to the characteristic peaks of graphene oxide sheets (see Supplementary material Fig. S3a, a broad peak in the high frequency area at about 3200 cm–1 attributed to the stretching mode of OH bond, a band at 1733 cm–1 assigned to the C=O stretching and a band at 1556 cm–1 referred to the C=C skeletal vibration), Si–O–Si and Si–O–C characteristic absorption peaks resulting from the bonding of the organosilane compounds to the layers were observed at 1092 and 1036 cm–1, respectively and are in good agreement with the literature [29]. The band observed around 1630 cm–1 in both FTIR spectra was assigned to the N–C–N stretching vibration [30]. In addition, asymmetric stretching of C=S vibration bands were observed around 1443 cm–1 both materials. Since Raman spectroscopy is used for identifying structural properties of carbon-based materials, such as fullerenes, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and graphene and its derivatives [31,32], it was also employed for characterization of graphene-based carbocatalysts. As shown in Fig. 1b, the presence of D and G bands at 1348 and 1596 cm–1 respectively clearly approves the presence of sp3 and sp2 carbon atoms in the GO sheets. ID/IG ratio provides valuable information about sp2 domain size in a carbon structure containing sp3 and sp2 bonds [33] and was found 0.939 for (S,S) and (R,R) GO-PATU. The observed ID/IG ratio after functionalization of GO from 0.896 to 0.939 refers to an increase in sp3 domain disorder and is in accordance with literature (see Supplementary material Fig. S3b for Raman spectrum of GO) [34]. Further confirmation of the functional groups in (S,S) and (R,R) GO-PATU was carried out by XPS analysis and the full range spectra of the prepared carbocatalysts were given in Fig. 2 a. Intense peaks were observed in the characteristic bond energies indicating the presence of C, O, N, Si and S atoms in the spectrum of both nanomaterials [29]. These peaks were obtained at 285.0, 531.8, 399.2, 102.1 and 161.8 eV for (S,S) GO-PATU, and also at 285.1, 532.3, 399.1, 102.3 and 161.4 eV for (R,R) GO-PATU, respectively. Compared to XPS of GO, XPS spectrum of (S,S) and (R,R) GO-PATU displayed novel peaks, which corresponds to N1s, Si2p and S2p, confirming the successful decoration of organosilane compounds on the GO backbone. The C/O ratios among the atomic percentages of the materials showed a notable difference from the starting material GO. In addition, the characteristic peak belonging to the S2p bond energy observed at about 162 eV due to the presence of sulfur atom clearly confirmed the existence of the thiourea group [35,36]. Besides, the deconvolution based on the S2p peaks of the sulfur atom contained in (S,S) GO-PATU indicated two unit moieties as shown in Fig. 2b appearing at 161.1 and 162.2 eV which corresponded to S2p3/2 ve S2p1/2 [37] similarly to (R,R) GO-PATU. After successful structural characterization, morphological analysis of graphene-based bifunctional heterogeneous nanomaterials was achieved by SEM and TEM techniques. The SEM and TEM images for both nanomaterial shown in Fig. 3 certainly confirmed the presence of nanoscaled sheets on newly prepared carbocatalysts. The wrinkles and overlaps similar to GO were observed in the SEM image. Furthermore, it should be noted that sheet-like perspective of GO is maintained after functionalization steps to obtain (S,S) and (R,R) GO-PATU. 3.2 Catalytic activity and recyclability of the graphene-based carbocatalysts (S,S)-GO-PATU and (R,R)-GO-PATU) in the asymmetric Michael addition reactions (S,S) GO-PATU, one of the heterogeneous catalysts that we prepared with the prediction that graphene could serve as an effective support material for primary amine-thiourea chiral units and provide the desired catalytic properties, was used for the optimization of conditions in the Michael reaction between isobutyraldehyde and trans-β-Nitrostyrene. The results are summarized in Table 1 . Water was first tried as the solvent and the Michael product was obtained with 44% yield and 47% ee (Table 1, entry 1). From the chiral HPLC analysis of Michael adduct 7a, it was determined that (S,S) GO-PATU selectively promoted the formation of (S) configurated enantiomer. In order to increase the yield and selectivity, PhCOOH (15 mol%), one of the commonly used Brønsted acid additive in the Michael reactions, was added to the reaction mixture in water, and a marginal increase was observed in the yield but the enantioselectivity remained the same (Table 1, entry 2). When the reaction was carried out in hexane, a decrease in both yield and enantioselectivity was observed (Table 1, entry 3). Gratifyingly, better results were obtained in terms of both yield and enantioselectivity in CH2Cl2 (Table 1, entry 4). Since obtaining both enantiomers of a biologically important chiral compound with high ee is highly desirable, organocatalysis to fulfill this goal would be a great choice [38]. There are few studies on the selective preparation of both enantiomers of products by organocatalytic Michael additions between aldehydes and nitroalkenes [39,40]. Thus, we also wanted to check the performance of (R,R) GO-PATU to form the opposite enantiomer and observed the reverse asymmetric induction (Table 1, entry 5). As can be seen from Table 1, several acidic (4-nitrobenzoic acid, l - and d-camphorsulfonic acids, l -tartaric acid) and basic additives (4-Dimetilaminopiridin, 1,4-Diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane) were also tested in DCM and water at room temperature or 4 °C in order to increase the yield and enantioselectivity (Table 1, 6–14). The best results were obtained in the presence of l - and d -camphorsulfonic acids at room temperature. After identifying the best conditions for the model reaction, in order to explore the general applicability of this enantioselective transformation, we studied substrate scope of Michael addition reaction using a variety of nitrostyrenes with isobutyraldehyde. According to the results given in Table 2 , the presence of various electron withdrawing and releasing groups in the aromatic rings of nitroalkenes slightly affected enantioselectivity (80–91% ee) and yields (66–78%). These results proves the general utility of graphene-based carbocatalysts (S,S) and (R,R) GO-PATU. We further extended the usability of newly designed graphene-based heterogeneous catalyst (S,S) GO-PATU by examining the performance in the asymmetric Michael addition of isobutyraldehyde (5a) and cyclopentacarboxaldehyde (5b) to maleimides. By this reaction, enantiomerically pure succinimides can be obtained and transformed to important biologically active compounds [41,42]. It is also known that the use of heterogeneous catalysts in this reaction is very limited in the literature [43,44]. The reactions were performed under optimized conditions and the results are given in Table 3 . The reactions generally gave the desired addition products moderate to high yields (58–85%) with good enantioselectivities (77–95% ee) and different electron donating as well as electron withdrawing groups were also well tolerated. Configuration of the addition products 9a-9f was determined as (S) by comparing HPLC retention times with previous reports [28,45]. Reusability of graphene-based chiral heterogeneous catalyst (S,S) GO-PATU was also examined in the asymmetric Michael addition reaction between isobutyraldehyde and trans-β-nitrostyrene. After completion of the first cycle, the catalyst was centrifuged and washed thoroughly with ethyl acetate, dried under vacuum and reused for the next run. The results obtained by recycling experiments are shown in Fig. 4 . The activity in terms of enantioselectivity started to decrease from the sixth use while the yield started to decrease gradually after the third run. Deactivation of the chiral centers on the surface or the reduction in the number of active sites due to the changes in the structure of catalyst could lead to yield decrease. But, the high ee values obtained until seventh cycle confirmed that the surviving chiral sites were effectively stereoselective [43]. Although the mechanistic aspect of the reactions requires further research, we propose that solid chiral graphene surface could play an important and active role in terms of the effect to the enantioselectivity. The activation of the aldehyde by the amine groups of chiral scaffold leads to formation of the enamine intermediate, while the nitroalkene/maleimide may be activated by a network of H-bonding interactions provided by thiourea moieties, camphorsulfonic acid and the carboxylic acids in the edges of catalyst. High enantioselectivity is observed due to the attack of enamine from only the re- or si- face of nitrostyrene or maleimide. 4 Conclusion In summary, conversion of enantiomerically pure 1,2-diaminocyclohexanes using 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane to organosilanes and inserting to the graphene surface covalently via reacting with graphene oxide produced (S,S) and (R,R) GO-PATU named carbocatalysts. The structural and morphological characterizations were performed by FT-IR, Raman spectroscopy, XPS, SEM and TEM. Bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts were utilized as multiple H-bond donor–acceptors in the asymmetric Michael addition reactions between aldehydes and nitrostyrenes/maleimides. The catalysts were found to be effective in terms of both yield and stereoselectivity. The best results (up to 85 yield; 95 ee) were obtained in dichloromethane at room temperature in the presence of d - and l -camphorsulfonic acid. Moreover, these metal-free carbocatalysts can be easily recovered and used for several times without substantial reduction in catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: Heterogeneous asymmetric catalysis based on earth-abundant carbon materials put together the advantages for the ease of separation, simple regeneration, and high stability of solid catalysts as well as acts as low-cost, environmentally friendly metal-free alternative to the metal-based catalysts. Two new bifunctional carbocatalysts [ (S,S) and (R,R) GO-PATU] were prepared by anchoring enantiomerically pure organosilanes bearing primary amine and thiourea groups to the graphene oxide (GO) skeleton covalently via silane coupling reaction. The surface modification of GO was analyzed by a combination of Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron spectroscopy (TEM) techniques. The catalytic performances of graphene-based materials were investigated in the asymmetric Michael addition reactions of α,α-disubstituted-aldehydes to nitrostyrenes and N-substituted-maleimides. The effects of solvents and Brønsted basic or acidic additives were evaluated using both catalysts and good yields (up to 85%) and stereoselectivities (up to 95% ee) were obtained in dichloromethane at room temperature in the presence of l - and d -camphorsulfonic acid. Besides, recycling and reusing studies of the catalysts were successfully performed.
coredata.dc:title: Primary amine–thiourea grafted graphene–based heterogeneous chiral catalysts for highly enantioselective Michael additions
